prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In the Cycle 0 observation toward L1527, the line intensities of the SO (J_N=7_6-6_5) and the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 400 mJy/(0.8" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.15 km/s. Considering that the radius of the centrifugal barrier is about 100 AU, we need the spatial resolution of 100 AU or smaller. In L1527, 0.6" resolution (~80 AU) is better to identify it, which is justified by the Band 7 (0.6") observation in Cycle 0. With the 0.6” beam, the above intensities are estimated to be higher than 184 mJy/beam. (It can be higher, depending on the existence of compact structures) With the rms noise of 7 mJy/beam we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 25 sigma or higher.
Considering the above estimation, we request the spatial resolution of 0.4" in this science goal, because L483 is located at the distance of 1.5 times larger than that of L1527. Although the line width is expected to be about 3.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.15 km/s, which is close to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Even if the intensities of the SO and CCH lines are 5 times weaker than those of L1527, we can image the distributions with higher than 5 sigma confidence level. Then, time estimation tells us the observing time of 1.08 hours.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. The NH2CHO line is a completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need almost full "12M array data rate" which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s.

In the Cycle 0 observation toward L1527, the line intensities of the SO (J_N=7_6-6_5) and the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 400 mJy/(0.8" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.15 km/s. Considering that the radius of the centrifugal barrier is about 100 AU, we need the spatial resolution of 100 AU or smaller. In L1527, 0.6" resolution (~80 AU) is better to identify it, which is justified by the Band 7 (0.6") observation in Cycle 0. With the 0.6" beam, the above intensities are estimated to be higher than 184 mJy/beam. (It can be higher, depending on the existence of compact structures) With the rms noise of 7 mJy/beam we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 25 sigma or higher.
Considering the above estimation, we request the spatial resolution of 0.6" in this science goal, because B335 is located at the similar distance to that of L1527. Although the line width is expected to be about 4.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.15 km/s which is close to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Even if the intensities of the SO and CCH lines are 5 times weaker than those of L1527, we can image the distributions with higher than 5 sigma confidence level. Then, time estimation tells us the observing time of 1.06 hours.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. The NH2CHO line is a completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need almost full "12M array data rate" which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s.

In the Cycle 0 observation toward L1527, the line intensities of the SO (J_N=7_6-6_5) and the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 400 mJy/(0.8" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.15 km/s. Considering that the radius of the centrifugal barrier is about 100 AU, we need the spatial resolution of 100 AU or smaller. In L1527, 0.6" resolution (~80 AU) is better to identify it, which is justified by the Band 7 (0.6") observation in Cycle 0. With the 0.6" beam, the above intensities are estimated to be higher than 184 mJy/beam. (It can be higher, depending on the existence of compact structures) With the rms noise of 7 mJy/beam we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 25 sigma or higher.
Considering the above estimation, we request the spatial resolution of 0.4" in this science goal, because NGC1333IRAS4A is located at the distance of about 1.5 times larger than that of L1527. Although the line width is expected to be about 2.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.15 km/s which is close to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Then, time estimation tells us the observing time of 1.15 hours. In this source, the SO (J_N=7_8-6_7) line is detected very brightly. However, the line consists of narrow (2.5 km/s) and broad (~10 km/s) component. The later is expected to originate from a molecular outflow. The former is expected to contain the spatially extended component, and hence, only a portion of the narrow component may come from the centrifugal barrier. The above high resolution observation can preferentially pick up the compact component (component from the centrifugal barrier, if exist) which we would like to observe. Thus, we need a similar quality image in comparison with other sources in this proposal. On the other hand, the intensity of the CCH line may be very weak in this source because NGC1333IRAS4A is a hot corino source and shows very low abundance of carbon chain molecules. Thus, we will obtain the CS (J=5-4) line image instead of that of CCH. According to the Cycle 0 result, the CS distribution is found to be similar to that of CCH. The intensity of the CS line is 160 mJy/0.8" beam. It is weaker than that of the CCH line, but the velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 15 sigma or higher can be obtained.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. The NH2CHO line is a completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need almost full "12M array data rate" which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s.

In the Cycle 0 observation toward L1527, the line intensities of the SO (J_N=7_6-6_5) and the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 400 mJy/(0.8" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.15 km/s. Considering that the radius of the centrifugal barrier is about 100 AU, we need the spatial resolution of 100 AU or smaller. In L1527, 0.6" resolution (~80 AU) is better to identify it, which is justified by the Band 7 (0.6") observation in Cycle 0. With the 0.6" beam, the above intensities are estimated to be higher than 184 mJy/beam. (It can be higher, depending on the existence of compact structures) With the rms noise of 7 mJy/beam we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 25 sigma or higher.
Considering the above estimation, we request the spatial resolution of 0.6" in this science goal because IRAS04365+2535 is located in the same parent cloud of L1527. Although the line width is expected to be about 2.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.15 km/s which is close to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Even if the intensities of the SO and CCH lines are 5 times weaker than those of L1527, we can image the distributions with higher than 5 sigma confidence level. In this source, the CCH line is actually detected with the intensity of 1 K with IRAM 30 m telescope which is 5 times weaker than that of L1527. Since this source is more evolved (Class I) than L1527 (Class 0) and the contribution of the extended component in expected to be smaller than that of L1527, the actual line intensity would be higher than 1/5 of the intensity observed in L1527. Then, time estimation tells us the observing time of 1.06 hours.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. The NH2CHO line is a completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need almost full "12M array data rate" which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s.

In the Cycle 0 observation toward L1527, the line intensities of the SO (J_N=7_6-6_5) and the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 400 mJy/(0.8" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.15 km/s. Considering that the radius of the centrifugal barrier is about 100 AU, we need the spatial resolution of 100 AU or smaller. In L1527, 0.6" resolution (~80 AU) is better to identify it, which is justified by the Band 7 (0.6") observation in Cycle 0. With the 0.6" beam, the above intensities are estimated to be higher than 184 mJy/beam. (It can be higher, depending on the existence of compact structures) With the rms noise of 7 mJy/beam we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 25 sigma or higher.
Considering the above estimation, we request the spatial resolution of 0.6" in this science goal, because Elias29 is located at the similar distance to that of L1527. Although the line width is expected to be 2-4 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.15 km/s which is close to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Then, time estimation tells us the observing time of 1.15 hours. In this source, the SO (J_N=7_8-6_7) line is detected brightly. However, the line consists of narrow (2 km/s) and relatively broad (4 km/s) component. The later would originate from molecular outflow. Furthermore, the former would contain the spatially extended component, and hence, only a portion of the spectra may come from the centrifugal barrier. The above high resolution observation can preferentially pick up the compact component (component from the centrifugal barrier, if exist) which we would like to observe. Thus, we need a similar quality image in comparison with other sources in this proposal. On the other hand, the intensity of the CCH line may be very weak in this source, because Elias29 is expected to be an evolved hot corino source, which generally shows very low abundances of carbon chain molecules. Thus, we will obtain the CS (J=5-4) line image instead of that of CCH. According to the Cycle 0 result, the CS distribution is found to be similar to that of CCH. The intensity of the CS line is 160 mJy/0.8" beam. It is weaker than that of the CCH line, but the velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 15 sigma or higher can be obtained.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. The NH2CHO line is a completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need almost full "12M array data rate" which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In star formation studies, one of the most important issues is when and how the rotationally supported disk is formed around a protostar. In this proposal, we approach this problem by chemistry. With our ALMA Cycle 0 observations toward the low-mass Class 0 protostar L1527, we discovered a drastic chemical change in the transition zone between the infalling rotating envelope and the inner disk. Carbon-chain molecules as well as CS mainly exist in the infalling rotating envelope, whereas SO selectively trace the transition zone. This drastic change seems to originate from the accretion shock in front of the centrifugal barrier. Thus, chemistry can highlights the transition zone. Moreover, the protostellar mass and the specific angular momentum can easily be derived by the radius of the centrifugal barrier and the rotation velocity there. Based on this success in L1527, we apply this method to 5 low-mass protostellar sources in the Class 0 and I stages with different chemical and physical characteristics to verify the applicability of this method. This observation will open a new avenue to study the physical and chemical evolution associated with disk formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
